Skip to main content
Ctrl+K
This is a community-supported SSVEP measure and aperiod analysis for EEG or other time series signal. If you'd like to contribute, check out our GitHub repository. Your contributions are welcome!

scut_ssvep_aperiod.ssvep_method.tdca.isPD(B)[source]#

Checks if the input matrix is positive-definite using Cholesky decomposition.

This function determines whether the matrix B is positive-definite by attempting to perform a Cholesky decomposition. If the decomposition succeeds, the matrix is positive-definite; otherwise, it is not.

Parameters:

B (ndarray) – Any matrix, shape (N, N).

Returns:

True if B is positive-definite, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

scut_ssvep_aperiod.ssvep_method.tdca.lagging_aug(X, n_samples, lagging_len, P, training)[source]#

Augment EEG signals with lagging.

Parameters:

  • X (ndarray) – Input EEG signals (n_trials, n_channels, n_points).

  • n_samples (int) – Number of delayed sample points.

  • lagging_len (int) – Lagging length.

  • P (ndarray) – Projection matrix (n_points, n_points).

  • training (bool) – True for training, False for testing.

Returns:

Augmented EEG signals (n_trials, (lagging_len + 1) * n_channels, n_samples).

Return type:

ndarray

Raises:

ValueError – If the length of X is not greater than lagging_len + n_samples.

scut_ssvep_aperiod.ssvep_method.tdca.nearestPD(A)[source]#

Finds the nearest positive-definite matrix to the input.

Parameters:

A (ndarray) – Any square matrix, shape (N, N).

Returns:

Positive-definite matrix closest to A.

Return type:

ndarray

References

N.J. Higham, “Computing a nearest symmetric positive semidefinite matrix” (1988): https://doi.org/10.1016/0024-3795(88)90223-6

scut_ssvep_aperiod.ssvep_method.tdca.proj_ref(Yf)[source]#

Calculate the projection matrix from Sin-Cosine reference signals.

Parameters:

Yf (ndarray) – Sin-Cosine reference signals (n_freq, 2 * num_harmonics, n_points).

Returns:

Projection matrix.

Return type:

ndarray

scut_ssvep_aperiod.ssvep_method.tdca.robust_pattern(W, Cx, Cs)[source]#

Transforms spatial filters to spatial patterns based on the method described in the literature.

This function constructs spatial patterns from spatial filters, which illustrates how to combine information from different EEG channels to extract signals of interest. For neurophysiological interpretation or visualization of weights, it is essential to derive activation patterns from the obtained spatial filters.

Parameters:

  • W (ndarray) – Spatial filters, shape (n_channels, n_filters).

  • Cx (ndarray) – Covariance matrix of EEG data, shape (n_channels, n_channels).

  • Cs (ndarray) – Covariance matrix of source data, shape (n_channels, n_channels).

Returns:

Spatial patterns, shape (n_channels, n_patterns), where each column represents a spatial pattern.

Return type:

ndarray

References

Haufe, Stefan, et al. “On the interpretation of weight vectors of linear models in multivariate neuroimaging.” Neuroimage 87 (2014): 96-110.

Notes

Use linalg.solve instead of inv to enhance numerical stability. For more details, see: - robintibor/fbcsp - https://ww2.mathworks.cn/help/matlab/ref/mldivide.html

scut_ssvep_aperiod.ssvep_method.tdca.tdca_feature(X, templates, W, M, Ps, lagging_len, n_components, training=False)[source]#

Compute the TDCA feature.

Parameters:

  • X (ndarray) – Input EEG signals (n_trials, n_channels, n_points).

  • templates (ndarray) – EEG template signals (n_freq, n_channels, n_points).

  • W (ndarray) – Spatial filters (n_channels, n_filters).

  • M (ndarray) – Common templates for all categories (n_channels, n_points).

  • Ps (list) – Projection matrices (n_freq, n_channels, n_points).

  • lagging_len (int) – Lagging length.

  • n_components (int) – Number of components.

  • training (bool) – True for training, False for testing.

Returns:

Correlation coefficients (n_freq,).

Return type:

list

scut_ssvep_aperiod.ssvep_method.tdca.xiang_dsp_feature(W, M, X, n_components)[source]#

Return DSP features as described in the paper.

Parameters:

  • W (ndarray) – Spatial filters (n_channels, n_filters).

  • M (ndarray) – Common template for all classes (n_channel, n_samples).

  • X (ndarray) – EEG test data (n_trials, n_channels, n_samples).

  • n_components (int, optional) – Length of the spatial filters; first k components to use (default is 1).

Returns:

Features (n_trials, n_components, n_samples).

Return type:

ndarray

Raises:

ValueError – If n_components is greater than the number of channels.

References

Liao, Xiang, et al. “Combining spatial filters for the classification of single-trial EEG in a finger movement task.” IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering 54.5 (2007): 821-831.

scut_ssvep_aperiod.ssvep_method.tdca.xiang_dsp_kernel(X, y)[source]#

DSP: Discriminative Spatial Patterns, only for two classes.

This function solves spatial filters with DSP by finding a projection matrix that maximizes the between-class scatter matrix and minimizes the within-class scatter matrix. Currently, it supports only two types of data.

Parameters:

  • X (ndarray) – EEG train data (n_trials, n_channels, n_samples) with mean removed.

  • y (ndarray) – Labels of EEG data (n_trials,).

Returns:

W (ndarray): Spatial filters (n_channels, n_filters). D (ndarray): Eigenvalues in descending order. M (ndarray): Mean value of all classes and trials (n_channel, n_samples). A (ndarray): Spatial patterns (n_channels, n_filters).

Return type:

tuple

Raises:

ValueError – If the number of components exceeds the number of channels.

References

Liao, Xiang, et al. “Combining spatial filters for the classification of single-trial EEG in a finger movement task.” IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering 54.5 (2007): 821-831.

scut_ssvep_aperiod.ssvep_method.tdca.data_path = 'D:\\data\\ssvep_dataset\\MNE-lee2019-ssvep-data\\session1\\s1\\sess01_subj01_EEG_SSVEP.mat'[source]#
